message_1:
Consider the following monthly data for a particular year:
January: 80, February: 85, March: 90, April: 94, May: 98, June: 101, July: 105, August: 110, September: 115, October: 118, November: 122, December: 126.

Using time series analysis, find the forecasted value for January of the next year if the trend is assumed to be linear.
message_2:
To find the forecasted value for January of the next year using a linear trend, we first need to find the slope of the trend line. We can do this by finding the average change in the data per month.

The data is as follows:

Month (t) | Value (y)
1 (Jan)   | 80
2 (Feb)   | 85
3 (Mar)   | 90
4 (Apr)   | 94
5 (May)   | 98
6 (Jun)   | 101
7 (Jul)   | 105
8 (Aug)   | 110
9 (Sep)   | 115
10 (Oct)  | 118
11 (Nov)  | 122
12 (Dec)  | 126

To find the slope (m), we can use the formula:

m = (Σ(t*y) - (Σt * Σy) / n) / (Σ(t^2) - (Σt)^2 / n)

where n is the number of data points (12 in this case), t is the month, and y is the value for that month.

First, we calculate the necessary sums:

Σt = 1 + 2 + ... + 12 = 78
Σy = 80 + 85 + ... + 126 = 1194
Σ(t*y) = 1*80 + 2*85 + ... + 12*126 = 9456
Σ(t^2) = 1^2 + 2^2 + ... + 12^2 = 650

Now, we can plug these sums into the formula for the slope:

m = (9456 - (78 * 1194) / 12) / (650 - (78)^2 / 12)
m = (9456 - 93492 / 12) / (650 - 6084 / 12)
m = (9456 - 7791) / (650 - 507)
m = 1665 / 143
m ≈ 11.64

Now that we have the slope, we can find the intercept (b) using the formula:

b = (Σy - m * Σt) / n
b = (1194 - 11.64 * 78) / 12
b = (1194 - 908.32) / 12
b ≈ 23.81

Now we have the linear trend equation:

y = 11.64t + 23.81

To forecast the value for January of the next year (t = 13), we can plug t = 13 into the equation:

y = 11.64 * 13 + 23.81
y ≈ 151.25

So, the forecasted value for January of the next year is approximately 151.25.
